Summary: I am sorry, but none of the reviews mention gourmet experiences at this hotel.

This hotel is near Restaurant Row on 46th Street, close to 9th, with hundreds of ethnic restaurants on the doorstep and many meal options right outside the door. Continental breakfast is served including coffee, juice, cereal, and rolls, and there is a small kitchenette available to guests.

The hotel has a Thai fusion restaurant called Kittichai and offers room service with Kittichai selections; breakfast is available, but some found it uninspired, and the lobby has a chocolate boutique. Some reviewers recommend nearby restaurants such as Balthazar, Barolo, Public, and Cubana Cafe.

The hotel has a Japanese/sushi restaurant called Blue Ribbon that is popular and serves as the hotel's room service, though some found the food to be overpriced and not outstanding. There is a Whole Foods across the street, with lots of food to go and Whole Foods in the Time Warner Center where they sell food by weight, so you only pay what you want to eat.

The hotel has a bar that serves food and the Silverleaf Tavern that offers tasty appetizers and cocktails; additionally, some reviewers recommend Moonstruck 244 Madison Avenue for burgers. Breakfast is available as a buffet or via room service, but some found it expensive.
The hotel has a lobby bar and is opening the Breslin restaurant, directed by April Bloomfeld, and offers room service from nearby restaurants. Complimentary breakfast includes coffee and croissants.

The hotel offers room service from The Mint, an Indian restaurant across the street, and the area around 2nd Avenue has several grocery stores and lots of restaurants. The hotel is near Smith & Wollensky's Steakhouse, and restaurants like Zarelas (Mexican), Angelos (Pizza), and a deli store.
The hotel has a full kitchen, and is surrounded by rated restaurants, delis and grocery stores. Barking Dog restaurant is next to the hotel.

While the Affinia Gardens doesn't have a restaurant, it has arrangements with nearby restaurants (Chinese, Italian, American Diner, Hamburger) for delivery for a $2 service charge, and a Food Emporium grocery store is located close by. Several reviewers enjoyed meals at JoJo's, Asia Grill, and Alice's Tea Cup, all located near the hotel.

The hotel has a restaurant called Niles which offers good food at reasonable prices and excellent room service. The hotel also has a kitchen area in each room and is close to many restaurants, delis, and bars.

The Affinia Shelburne has an on-site restaurant, Rare Bar and Grill, that is known for its burgers and is a popular spot for locals. Some reviewers mention enjoying breakfast at Rare, while others recommend nearby delis for more affordable options.
This hotel is near a supermarket and a Chinese restaurant/takeaway. The hotel provides a selection of tea, coffee, and snacks in the lobby, and suggests restaurants to guests.

The Algonquin Hotel features an Oak Room restaurant that is well-priced, offers great steaks and destination dining, though some found breakfast service slow and non-existent.
Some reviewers thought the drinks were excellent in the hotel bar.
I am sorry, but this hotel summary does not contain information about gourmet food or dining experiences.

The hotel has a Japanese restaurant and a cocktail bar connected to it.
Free coffee is available in the lobby all day.

This hotel does not have a restaurant, but there are small cafes nearby for breakfast and restaurants within walking distance. Some reviewers recommend specific places, such as a diner one block back on 107th Street, restaurants on Broadway, and a cafe on the corner for pancakes or bagels.

Dominico's restaurant served excellent mid-priced food with a nice bar where Laura remembered guests' drinks each day, and there are lots of good small eateries (delis, diners, Indian Thai, Cuban, Japanese) and shops in the neighborhood. Blooms Delicatessen has great food and service, and Scotty's diner around the corner is recommended for a great, large, inexpensive breakfast.

The hotel has an over-priced restaurant on the 26th floor with nice views, a restaurant on top of the tower, and a small restaurant directly across the street. The restaurant on the top floor has beautiful views, food prices similar to home prices, drinks were little pricey.

The Belleclaire Hotel does not have a restaurant on site, but offers room service from the Manhattan Diner across the street which offers a 24-hour delivery service, a large menu, and reasonable prices. There are many options for eating nearby, such as Big Nicks Burger Joint, Patsy's Pizzeria, Zabar's, and H&H Bagels.

The hotel has a rooftop bar and restaurant with great views, but some reviews indicate the food and atmosphere can be disappointing. There are several restaurants in the surrounding neighborhood, including the Ritz Diner and Luscious Thai.

The hotel is located in Chinatown and near Little Italy, surrounded by Chinese, Thai, and Vietnamese restaurants and within walking distance of Joe's Shanghai restaurant. There are also many Chinese bakeries and fruit stands nearby.
I am sorry, but there is no information about gourmet dining in the provided hotel reviews.

This hotel offers a fully-stocked kitchen with a refrigerator, oven, stove, microwave, and dishwasher, allowing guests to prepare their meals. There are also restaurants next door, but some reviewers found them to be expensive with only okay food.
The hotel is located near several restaurants and cafes, with Les Halles Brasserie mentioned as a must-go. A Brazilian tapas restaurant called Salud is also recommended.

The Blue Moon Hotel is near several restaurants and cafes: Orchard 88, Little Giant, Cafe Katja, Cananis restaurant, Barrio Chino, Tre, Il Cortile ,The Nolita House, Katz's Deli, Yonah Schimmel Knishes, Noah's Ark, Russ and Daughters. Breakfast is served with bagels, pastries, juice and coffee.

The hotel offers a complimentary continental breakfast with bagels, muffins, pastries, coffee, tea, juice, and fruit. Some reviewers mentioned nearby dining options, such as Naturally Tasty diner, Houston's restaurant, Blue Smoke, and Ilili.
This hotel has kitchens in the suites and is near a grocery store and several restaurants. The Carnegie Deli delivers to the suites.

Many rooms have a full kitchen with a full-size refrigerator, two-burner electric stove, dishwasher, sink, dishes, utensils, cook pots, and a coffee maker. There is a Mexican take-out across the street.
I am sorry, but there is no information about gourmet food or dining at this hotel.

The hotel is near many food and drink options on the street, and JP Clark's Irish pub is at the end of the street. The mini bars in the rooms were not yet stocked and the bar in the lobby was still under construction.

Tony's Italian restaurant is next to the hotel, and a few reviewers mentioned good pizza and food delivered to the room. The hotel has a Rick's Cafe which provides free wine and cheese in the evening with a complimentary breakfast including quality food.
The hotel restaurant, Town, is considered very good by reviewers, though some found it pricey; breakfast is included, and room service is available. There are many food options around the hotel.

These reviews mention proximity to restaurants like Cookshop, Galaxy Diner, Empire Diner, Lasagna Ristorante, and Murray's Bagels, as well as Chelsea Market. Some reviewers recommend specific restaurants, including Billy's Bakery for cheesecake and cupcakes and La Bergamote for coffee and French pastries.

Chelsea Pines Inn is near Balducci's, a gourmet deli, and Chelsea Market; breakfast includes bagels, cream cheese, and smoked salmon on the weekends, with homemade breads, muffins, scones, and salmon and fresh cream during the week. The hotel staff can also provide dining recommendations.
These reviews do not contain information about gourmet experiences at the hotel. The hotel offers complimentary coffee and pastries and is located near many restaurants and bars.

The hotel has an excellent restaurant, DB Bistro Moderne, with room service available, and the hotel also offers a French continental breakfast. Some reviewers recommend the DB Bistro for dinner or room service, especially the burgers, and others praise the breakfast menu, particularly the brioche.

The Solita Soho is near Little Italy and Chinatown, offering walking distance access to various restaurants. Some reviews mention recommendations from staff and nearby restaurants such as Lombardi's pizza, Katz's Delicatessen, Ferrara's Italian bakery, Balthazaar's french bakery, and Mexican Radio.

This hotel has an on-site restaurant (Bull Run Restaurant) that serves breakfast, lunch, and dinner, however, some reviews claim it is overpriced; delivery from local restaurants is also available. Breakfast is sometimes served as a buffet in the hotel restaurant.

The reviews do not contain information about gourmet food or specific dining experiences in or near the hotel; most reviewers mention eating at Cafe Manhattan across the street. The hotel has an adjoining restaurant that looked to be a bit high-end, with an overpriced breakfast and adequate dinner menu with mediocre food.

The hotel has a restaurant called the Terrace Club on the 7th floor, and also offers room service from a selection of home delivery meals. Some reviewers mention the breakfast having good views from the roof top balcony, and others recommend avoiding the Terrace restaurant because of poor service and quality.

This hotel is next to a Chinese takeout place, near a "Greek Deli" convenience market, and has a breakfast that includes breads, hard boiled eggs, cereal, juice, milk and donuts. Some reviewers mention several nearby restaurants and bars.

Brendan's Bar/Restaurant is attached to the hotel where breakfast is served, and guests can receive 15% off their meal there. The hotel is near many restaurants, with some reviewers specifically mentioning O'Reilley's, Keen's Steakhouse, Chipotle Mexican Grill, Korean restaurants, and Pax deli.

There is a Sichuan hot pot restaurant around the corner on Canal Street that serves authentic and spicy food, and the Chinatown Ice Cream Factory is two blocks away. The hotel is also near a dumpling restaurant and a place that has a $2.50 lunch special and is within walking distance of Little Italy.

The hotel offers a free continental breakfast consisting of bagels, toast, cereals, yogurt, fruit, juice, coffee, and tea, with St Andrew's Pub and Restaurant across the street, and John's Shanghai next door. Restaurant Row is located a block away and 9th Ave has less expensive dining options.

The hotel is near many restaurants on 8th and 9th Ave, with 9th Ave offering less expensive options. The hotel offers a free continental breakfast with items such as waffles, bagels, pastries, cereal, fruit, yogurt, coffee, and juice.

I am sorry, but there is no information about gourmet food or experiences in the reviews. There are mentions of a basic continental breakfast with items like waffles, pastries, and cereal, and some reviewers noted nearby restaurants with halal, Pakistani, or buffet-style food.
I am sorry, but I cannot answer your question from the hotel reviews provided because there is no mention of gourmet food, fine dining, or acclaimed restaurants at or near the hotel.

The hotel's restaurant was not open yet at the time of the reviews, but the staff could arrange for food from nearby eateries. The continental breakfast was served in the bar and included yogurt, cheese and meats, fresh juices, and good coffee.

This hotel has a cafe attached and is near a bagel shop, Zucker's, a Starbucks, a deli, a nail spa, a Mexican restaurant, Maryann's, a French cafe, Cosmpolitan Cafe, a soda shop, and old-fashioned ice cream shop. Several reviewers recommend the cafe attached to the hotel, cafe next door, and soda shop.

The hotel has a restaurant that serves a breakfast buffet with made-to-order omelets, cooked-to-order eggs, waffles, and fresh fruit, though some found it overpriced and not great. There are many dining options nearby, including the Red Flame diner on 42nd and 6th, Pax Wholesome Foods on the corner of Avenue of the Americas and 40th Street, Duke's Cafe, Arno's for Italian eats, and Harrie's Bakery, but some reviewers advise caution regarding concierge recommendations for dinner.

The hotel has a restaurant and bar on the first floor, but some reviewers found it uninteresting. Some reviewers recommend nearby restaurants such as Pinnocios (Italian), Zebu Grill, Cafe D'Alsace, Kinsale Pub, Madison's, and Sarabeth's.

The hotel has an attached restaurant called Salmon River, and a deli next door called Charlie's that is open 24 hours and delivers. Some reviewers found the Salmon River restaurant to be pricey with limited selection, while others found it to have excellent food and good value.

This hotel has a partnership with Outback Steakhouse for room service and is near Houston's restaurant in the Citicorp Building.
It is also near many restaurants, bars, delis, and coffee shops including Ess-a-Bagel, Azure, Madison Restaurant, Bice, Smith & Wollensky's, and the Pig and Whistle.

The Crosby Street Hotel offers tasty and timely room service with options for both adults and children. The chef is willing to accommodate specific requests, such as making fresh salsa daily. The hotel restaurant has a selection of delicious wines and the bar offers over 400 bottles.

The Crowne Plaza has outrageously expensive in-hotel dining, though there are cheaper and better restaurants outside the hotel. Breakfast was considered good, with a great addition to the buffet being Rice Krispies with fresh blueberries and strawberries.

The hotel has a restaurant, Joe G's, that serves Italian food and gives a discount to hotel guests; some reviewers found it to be expensive. There are many restaurants in the area including the Carnegie Deli and the Soup Nazi.

Several reviewers mention the convenience of the hotel's location to numerous restaurants and eateries, although the hotel restaurant itself receives mixed reviews. Some reviewers enjoyed the breakfast buffet, while others found it overpriced or disappointing.

The Doubletree Chelsea has a restaurant called "Cheltons" where the executive chef, Chef Michael, prepares dishes like rack of lamb with sweet potato puree. One reviewer was delighted by the food and service at the restaurant.

The hotel restaurant receives mixed reviews, with some finding the breakfast buffet mediocre and overpriced while others enjoyed the limited menu options. Several reviews recommend nearby dining options outside the hotel.

The hotel has an Italian restaurant on site called Serafina that serves pizza and pasta and an attached restaurant that plays good music with a DJ. There is also a restaurant next door called Amalia that serves Roasted red pepper soup, Grilled Stuffed Ribeye steak, and Creme Brulee.

The hotel offers turndown service with sweet treats, complimentary buffet breakfast, and is located near restaurants such as Bouley's bakery and restaurant. The hotel restaurant and bar are available, but the bar only serves beer and wine due to the lack of a liquor license.

The Dylan Hotel has an on-site restaurant, although some reviews mention that the hotel restaurant and bar were closed for a period of time, with promises of a new restaurant opening soon. Some reviewers enjoyed the restaurant, with one mentioning an exceptional steak, while others found the food mediocre or the breakfast service poor.

This hotel has a kitchen in every room and is close to many stores and restaurants, though the hotel restaurant is closed for remodeling. There is a sushi restaurant next door, and many nearby delis, diners, and take-out options are mentioned.

The hotel offers a complimentary continental breakfast with bagels, muffins, pastries, cereal, fruit, coffee, tea, and juice; discount coupons are provided for a nearby restaurant. Some reviewers mentioned nearby restaurants on 9th Avenue and 46th Street (Restaurant Row) and diners.

The hotel offers a complimentary cooked-to-order breakfast with omelets, bacon, and pancakes, as well as a Manager's Reception with free drinks and snacks. There are several restaurants within the hotel complex, including Chevy's (Mexican) and Applebee's, with various dining opportunities near Ground Zero.

Ed's Chowder House is attached to the hotel, has fantastic staff and food, and is one of the nicest places people ate during their stay, and the hotel also has P.J. Clarke's, a pub-type place with fresh raw oysters. There are many delicious restaurants and lovely shops nearby.

These apartments have fully equipped kitchens, allowing guests to prepare their own meals, and are located near delis and restaurants. Some reviewers mentioned enjoying nearby restaurants such as 2nd Street Deli, Ali Baba for Turkish food, and Rocky's for pizza.
The hotel offers a breakfast buffet with cereal, toast, muffins, juice, scrambled eggs, and bacon. There are many diners and cafes nearby.

The hotel has an adjoining restaurant (separate ownership) with a very nice bar off the lobby, and is near many good neighborhood (non touristy) restaurants nearby; Sarabeth's and Fred's are within walking distance. A breakfast buffet on the 2nd floor is offered at $12 per person, and Zabar's deli is only three blocks away.

This hotel does not have a bar or restaurant, but it is close to many excellent and not very expensive restaurants on 9th street and in Hell's Kitchen. The hotel offers a free breakfast with breakfast sandwiches, but some reviewers suggest more fresh items and that the breakfast is standard budget hotel fare.

The Fitzpatrick Grand Central features the Wheeltapper Pub, offering Irish-themed food and drink, and is near Grand Central Station's dining concourse and market. Breakfast receives mixed reviews: some enjoyed it but found it pricey, while others recommend nearby options.

The Fitzpatrick Manhattan has a restaurant that serves good food, including an Irish breakfast, but some reviewers found it overpriced. The bar offers light snacks and is a great place to chat with fellow guests.

The hotel restaurant was only open for breakfast and the restaurant was only open for breakfast but the food and service were good. The hotel has a small bar within this area which seemed fairly busy most nights.
This hotel is near a Whole Foods Market and some restaurants. The breakfast in the hotel restaurant was ok.

The hotel restaurant is not highly rated, with recommendations to eat at nearby restaurants and delis, including the Jacques Torres chocolate store around the corner. Some reviewers mentioned the Aqua Grill, Cafe Borgia, and Archipelago restaurants as being good options nearby.

I did not find any information about gourmet restaurants or food in the hotel reviews. There is a mention of a small restaurant on premise, a cafe in the Port Authority, and Lenny's and the Westway Diner nearby.

The hotel has multiple dining options including L'Atelier de Joel Robuchon, 57 Restaurant, and TY Bar, though some found the food selection limited or overpriced. The hotel is also located near other restaurants such as TAO and Aureole.

The hotel has a restaurant called Libertine, and some reviewers noted the availability of breakfast, pastries and coffee in the lobby; some reviewers recommended nearby restaurants and diners. Room service is available, and the mini-bar is stocked with Dean and Deluca items.

The Gramercy Park Hotel has a Chinese restaurant from Nobu, and the Rose Bar serves great food/drinks. The hotel also offers room service, although some reviewers found it expensive and not that tasty.

The hotel has a restaurant, the Commodore Grill, with a breakfast menu and a more sophisticated atmosphere, and the Manhattan Sky Restaurant Bar with breakfast. Room service is available, but is generally considered very expensive by reviewers.

The hotel restaurant, Locanda Verde, is highly recommended with excellent food and a neighborhood feel; the hotel also offers organic eggs from an upstate farm for breakfast and a complimentary snack basket with treats. The hotel restaurant Ago, which was previously in the hotel, was in a lovely lofty space, but the food was barely adequate.

Some reviewers recommend nearby restaurants such as Nick's & Stef's Steakhouse, Brendans, RUB (bbq), and Lombardis (pizza). The hotel provides complimentary breakfast with hot and cold items, and 24/7 coffee, tea, and juice.

This hotel does not have a restaurant or bar but is close to many food places, including some excellent Korean restaurants on 32nd street. The hotel offers a complimentary breakfast with hot and cold items, and there is coffee and tea available 24/7.
This hotel offers a free breakfast buffet, but some guests found it basic and used polystyrene cups/bowls/plates. There are various restaurants and a Whole Foods grocery store nearby.

Many reviewers appreciated the free breakfast with a variety of options. Some reviewers mentioned nearby restaurants, including Balthazar, Blue Ribbon Sushi, Lupes Mexican restaurant, Mooncake, and Suzie's Chinese.

The hotel offers a free breakfast buffet with items such as cold cereal, scrambled eggs, sausage, oatmeal, bagels, and toast. Some reviewers recommend the Carbone Ristorante, a small family-owned Italian restaurant with pizza, located around the block.

This hotel is near many restaurants including the Bridge Cafe, a French restaurant at 259 Front Street, and Bon Amici, an Italian restaurant. Breakfast is included and there are various hot items every morning, fresh fruit, pancakes, and scrambled eggs.

This hotel does not have a restaurant, but some reviewers mention a good cafe next door, as well as delis and a Greek restaurant across the street. The hotel offers a basic complimentary continental breakfast in the lobby.
The hotel has on-property restaurants, but nothing available for a meal between 3:00 p.m. and 5:30 p.m.; the Hilton Club offers complimentary breakfast and a daily cocktail reception.

This hotel offers a breakfast buffet with eggs cooked to order and French toast on demand, and is near a Whole Foods and various cafes/delis. Some reviewers recommend Mustang Sally's, located across 7th Ave, and The Bread Factory cafe for breakfast.

This Hilton Garden Inn serves breakfast only, with a breakfast buffet that includes made-to-order omelets, but some found it overpriced; however, there are many restaurants and delis nearby, including Korean options. Some recommend Keens Chop House around the corner for steak.
Pigalles restaurant serves French cuisine and a plated cooked-to-order American breakfast. A grocery store is located across the street and there are delis nearby.

The hotel has a restaurant that serves hearty breakfasts, though not complimentary; a fancy French restaurant is next door, but not recommended due to noise and expense. There are many restaurants in the surrounding Tribeca neighborhood and nearby Soho and Chinatown.

The hotel has a NY Marketplace restaurant with a $30 per person all-you-can-eat breakfast buffet, though some reviewers found the food quality to be bad and the prices to be high. There are a wide variety of eating options nearby ranging from inexpensive delis up to elegant restaurants.

While some reviewers enjoyed the food in the restaurant, others found it expensive and unimaginative, recommending nearby cafes instead; Applebee's is connected to the hotel and provides a cheaper breakfast alternative. The Above restaurant and bar are located on the 21st floor, and there are mixed opinions on the quality of service there.
This hotel is a Holiday Inn Express, so it does not feature gourmet dining. However, there are a number of food outlets, restaurants, delis, and bars near the hotel.

The hotel is near Hell's Kitchen and Restaurant Row, with upscale Mexican cuisine at Hell's Kitchen restaurant and pre-theater specials at Basiliica across the street. There's also a cute restaurant called Westway around the corner on 8th street.
This hotel offers a complimentary breakfast buffet with a good selection of food, including hot items like eggs, sausage, and pancakes. Some reviewers found better breakfast options nearby.

Many reviewers mention the hotel's proximity to Chinatown and Little Italy, with easy access to many restaurants; some recommend specific restaurants such as Lombardi's and Angelo's. Some reviewers found the hotel restaurant to be bland and disappointing, while others enjoyed specific aspects of the hotel breakfast.

This hotel has a restaurant and bar but many reviewers recommend eating at restaurants and diners outside the hotel, including the Morning Star Restaurant, Route 66, Brooklyn Diner, Thai Basil, Puccini, Kashkaval and Sombrero. Some reviewers found the hotel breakfast good, while others found it pricey.

The hotel has a restaurant on the premises, but some reviewers found the food and breakfast to be expensive; there are delis, diners, and a Whole Foods nearby. The food in the bar is fabulous with huge portions, and the restaurant has half-price drinks during happy hour with an owner who does the cooking.

This hotel is near Gramercy Cafe, Mumbles Restaurant, Pete's Tavern, Casa Mono, Chino, Pure Food and Wine restaurant, Gramercy Diner, Mariella's Pizza, Stardust cafe, Sunburst, Corbet Conley, and Paquito's. Duane Reade drugstore and Whole Foods supermarket are also within walking distance.

I am sorry, but the provided reviews do not contain information about gourmet food or culinary experiences. Some reviews mention nearby restaurants, including a pizzeria, Italian restaurant, sushi restaurant, deli, and diners, but the reviews do not focus on gourmet dining.

This hotel does not offer meals, though it is next door to a Starbucks and a breakfast cafe. There is also a deli next door called the Oxford, and a list of nearby restaurants that deliver to the hotel.

Hotel 41 offers a complimentary breakfast with bagels, pastries, juice and coffee, and its bar serves food and happy hour with good prices. Some reviewers mentioned the availability of pub fare and the presence of a self-service coffee machine with latte and cappuccino.
I am sorry, but the provided reviews do not contain information about the availability of gourmet food. They mention ongoing renovations, rooms with TV, and the location of the hotel.

The Hotel Beacon has a kitchenette in every room and is across the street from Fairway Market, Citarella, and Zabar's, offering options for groceries, fresh produce, deli, and gourmet items. The hotel is next door to Viand Cafe, and within walking distance of many other restaurants.

The Hotel Chandler offers a $16-18 breakfast buffet with bacon, eggs, pastries, cereal, and fruit, with additional items like pancakes and french toast available upon request; there are also several restaurants and delis near the hotel. Some reviewers recommend specific nearby restaurants including Ravagh Persian Grill, Feastra deli, Keko's, Moonstruck Diner, ICHI UMI sushi buffet, Vezzo pizza, Grand Schizwan Chinese, The Crooked Fork, Hangawi vegetarian, La Giara Italian, Jackson Hole burgers, Pax, Guy & Gillard cafe, and Penelope's cafe.

The hotel is near numerous restaurants, a great bakery, a Starbucks on the corner, and a Duane Reade drugstore one block over; some rooms have a kitchenette with a refrigerator and a 2-burner stove. Several reviewers recommend nearby restaurants such as Les Halles, Susie's Kitchen deli, and Miss K's deli.
The hotel offers a continental breakfast with pastries from Balthazar bakery, gourmet coffee, cheeses, and fresh fruit. Katz's Deli is a few blocks away from the hotel.
The Hotel Elysee is near several notable restaurants including Oceana, Cellini, and Bill's Gay Nineties Restaurant. The Monkey Bar, located in the hotel, serves Asian fusion cuisine.

ONO, the hotel's Japanese restaurant, has been noted for the quality and creativity of its cuisine, with specific dishes like crab and caviar pizza highlighted. Some reviewers enjoyed breakfast at Ono, which includes fresh fruit and berries, while others recommend the restaurants in the surrounding Meatpacking District, like Spice Market and Pastis.

The Hotel Giraffe is located near many excellent restaurants, such as Tabla, Gramercy Tavern, and Union Square Cafe; Additionally, the hotel offers a complimentary cheese and wine/champagne selection at the lobby, and takeout from a restaurant.

The Grand Union Hotel has a Captain's Cafe and is near various diners and coffee shops, with a few reviewers specifically recommending the Captain's Cafe for breakfast. It is also located in Korea Town, with many Korean restaurants nearby.

The hotel restaurant, Blu, is considered the best in the area, with stand-out dishes such as Gnocchi with Butternut Squash soup; a Greek Diner at the end of the block provides great and relatively cheap breakfast.

The Hotel Mela has a French bistro offering room service and the hotel is near multiple restaurants, including Virgils BBQ, Red Flame, AKDENIZ, Roxy's and Jack's. Some reviewers recommend the nearby Red Flame Diner for breakfast.
The Hotel Metro has an attached Metro Grill which serves steak, fries and cheesecake. O'Reilly's Off Fifth is also located 4-5 doors down.

The Hotel Newton is next door to the Key West Diner, which offers room service, cheap breakfasts, and a wide variety of menu items; nearby Amsterdam & Colombus Avenue also has many restaurants and bars, as well as Gabriela's Mexican restaurant and Roth's Steakhouse. Other restaurants mentioned include Gennaro's Italian restaurant and OUEST restaurant.

The hotel includes a restaurant, Thor, with good food and a complimentary breakfast that includes pastries from Balthazar. Some reviewers enjoyed the food, while others found it pricey and preferred neighborhood options like Katz's Deli.
The hotel has a restaurant attached that serves decent food, though some found it slightly overpriced. There is also a gourmet grocery store within a block and several cafes and delis in the area.
This hotel does not have a restaurant, however, there are several delis and bars next door or across the street. The Cranberry Buffet next door is open 24 hours.

This hotel has an attached restaurant and is near many Korean restaurants, as it's located in Koreatown, with a deli across the street open late. Some reviewers enjoyed the complimentary breakfast, while others found it basic, with limited options like bagels, doughnuts, and pastries.
Sarabeth's is downstairs or next door, offering a convenient dining option. The hotel offers a complimentary continental breakfast with bagels, pastries, and fruit.

The hotel offers a restaurant and a cafeteria, though some reviewers note they are overpriced. Some specific items mentioned were Thomas Keller's Bouchon Bakery in the Time Warner building, lobster mac and cheese, and crab cakes.

The hotel restaurant was under construction during the review period, but the hotel is near Restaurant Row and offers in-room dining and has partnerships with nearby diners, which deliver 24/7. Some reviewers mentioned pre/post theater dinner recommendations such as Becco-Italian and Room Service-Thai.

The Inn New York City provides a kitchen stocked with wine, cheese, quiche, milk, oj, water, bagels, danishes, oatmeal, and coffee; other snacks include cheeses and quiche, fresh fruit, and gourmet ground coffee. Guests can also shop at nearby gourmet food stores such as Fairway & Zabar's to prepare meals in their suite's kitchen.

The Barclay Intercontinental's breakfast buffet is quite extensive, but most things are cold, while weekend buffets are USD 39.00; the hotel is near delis and Scafu pub, and the restaurant offers weekend buffets and an omelette station.

The hotel features a restaurant with Michelin star quality food and a new restaurant (South Gate) with a menu based on the local availability of the freshest food from the Farmer’s Market. The hotel also has a lobby lounge that offers high tea.

The Kitano has an excellent Japanese restaurant called Hakubai, with authentic food preparation, as well as the Garden Cafe for casual dining. Some reviewers enjoyed a breakfast buffet with Japanese specialty items.

Many reviewers enjoyed the free breakfast that included bagels, toast, donuts, cereal, yogurt, granola bars, fresh fruit and juices, although a few found the food and coffee to be of poor quality. The hotel is located in Korea Town, surrounded by Korean restaurants that are open 24 hours.
The hotel is near B Bar and Grill, which serves coffee, brunch, and burritos; a sushi bar; and Five Points, which serves burgers. Some rooms have kitchenettes.

Norma's is a breakfast place with award-winning brunch that people line up for, with highlights such as a super dinner from room service. The hotel also includes a burger joint known for the best burgers, as well as a French restaurant.

The hotel offers a complimentary continental breakfast with fresh pastries, and there is also complimentary wine and cheese in the evenings. Madison & Vine, an upscale bistro on the ground floor, also serves delicious fare.

The hotel restaurant lays claim to the original "Power Breakfast" and the breakfast room is excellent, populated mostly by local power-brokers; there are some great, cheap diners within a couple blocks walk. The hotel restaurant, The Library, is nice and has good food, and the room service was excellent and overall it was great value for money.
The hotel has an on-site restaurant, "the Post House," and offers room service from there; breakfast is served in the Pembrooke Room. Some suites have kitchenettes stocked with snacks and drinks.

The Mandarin Oriental has two restaurants, Asiate (with great views, Zagat's top-rated decor, tasting menu, and Japanese and European flavors) and Jean-Georges (across the road in the Trump Tower), plus reasonable food at the Time Warner Center. Bouchon Bakery is on the 3rd Floor, and Per Se is in the same building.

The Milford Plaza does not have a restaurant but is near plenty of restaurants, including Frankie and Johnnie's, the Westway Cafe, Juniors, Carve, and Smithy's. Some reviewers recommend Sardi's, Lombardi's Pizzeria, Carmines, Tick Tock Diner, Oyster Bar, and Famous Dave's BBQ.

Some reviewers enjoyed breakfast in the hotel, while others found it expensive and preferred nearby diners. There's also a French restaurant on the east side of the hotel, delis, and a nearby Whole Foods.

Some reviewers recommend dining at Virgil's Barbeque, known for Southern-style Thanksgiving feasts, or at Ruby Tuesdays. However, others mention that there are a lot of affordable dining choices nearby, and food service at the hotel is uninspiring.

The Ambassador Grill operates only for breakfast, with a $19 buffet option, and the hotel restaurant does not offer lunch or dinner. There are nearby options to eat and drink from on 2nd or 3rd Avenue, and 44th Street has a little place on the corner called Plaza Delhi that offers pancakes and bagels.
This hotel does not have a restaurant or food service, but offers complimentary coffee and tea. Several reviewers mention good restaurants, diners and pubs located nearby.

The hotel restaurant, Asia de Cuba, is one of the best spots in NY for happy hour and dinner, and offers complimentary breakfast with a good start to the day with breads, cereals, fruit, juice and coffee. Some guests also ate dinner at Asia de Cuba and found that to be fantastic.
This hotel has a full kitchen with a fridge, stove/range, dishwasher, coffee maker, pots and pans, dishes, and silverware. There are lots of restaurants, grocery stores, and delis nearby.
The hotel is near Penelope's restaurant and Brasil Coffee House; some reviewers recommend the Bagelry and Murray Hill Diner for breakfast. There are also several restaurants and cafes nearby.

Roy's restaurant is located within the hotel, and a few reviewers noted the availability of good breakfast and brunch options. The 85 west restaurant has a decent menu but is a bit pricy, with one reviewer noting a $20 burger.

Some reviewers mentioned Avra and David Burke Towne House as recommended nearby restaurants, while others found the hotel restaurant food to be average and overpriced. The hotel is close to many restaurants, coffee shops, and bars.

The hotel has multiple restaurants including The View, a revolving restaurant on the top floor, and a Starbucks on both the 8th floor and street level. Some reviewers recommend Juniors across the street for diner food and cheesecake and Carmine's for Italian food.

The hotel features the Gilt restaurant, a 2-Michelin star establishment, and the Istana restaurant. Some reviewers recommend a pre-theater prix fix meal at Gilt or highlight the quality of food at the wedding held in Gilt restaurant.

The hotel has a small bar/restaurant that is sometimes closed for refurbishment; though, there is room service and complimentary continental breakfast. Some reviewers recommend nearby restaurants such as Patsy's, Bonne Soupe, Blue Fin and Cranberry Deli, which has a great selection of food for a reasonable price.

Some reviewers found the cafe average, while others thought it was great with am amazing view; the breakfast buffet had an amazing choice of items. Reviews mention Cafe Nicole restaurant with amesing view.
The hotel is near many delicious restaurants, Chinatown, Little Italy, and cafes. The hotel rooms also have a kitchen with dishware, pots, pans and cutlery.

The Fireside Restaurant and Bar at the hotel was really nice, offering good food and a place for a late-night drink, though some reviewers found the food expensive. The hotel's restaurant offers an unusual dinner menu, or guests can find options like Isadora's deli across the street or Europa on Madison Avenue nearby.

On The Ave provides convenient access to Citarella for gourmet food and Fatty Crab for great cocktails and food (both located downstairs), as well as being across the street from Manhattan Diner for tasty, affordable breakfasts. The hotel is also located near "Good enough to eat" restaurant, and near Zabar's, a must-see if you love food.

The hotel is near many good-priced eateries, restaurants, delis, and bars, with recommendations for Shining Star restaurant/café, Lenny’s, Bourbon Street, The Gin Mill, Brother Jimmy’s, Swagat, Ocean Grill, Evelyn Lounge, Shine Star, and Alice's Tea Cup. Some reviewers mention enjoying breakfast at the Columbus St. Deli, delis on Amsterdam and Broadway, a store across the street from the hotel that had a delicious chicken sandwich, and local delis.

Some reviewers found the hotel restaurant to be expensive and not worth the money, while others enjoyed the breakfast buffet; the Carnegie Deli is located next door. There are several restaurants and delis located near the hotel.

The Park South Hotel has an attached restaurant called Black Duck, which has received good reviews and offers seafood-oriented cuisine. Some reviewers enjoyed the Black Duck restaurant's atmosphere, food, wine selection, and jazz music.

The hotel has one restaurant called Fives, which some reviewers found acceptable for hotel dining, while others considered it overpriced; there is also a lobby bar where guests can get good snacks, and a rooftop bar. Some reviewers noted that New York has many restaurants and advised against eating in hotels in general.

The Phillips Club is located near Balducci's, a gourmet grocery store, and offers fully-equipped kitchens in its rooms, allowing guests to prepare their own meals. There are also many restaurants located in the area.
The Plaza Athenee's restaurant, Arabelle, is considered good with a nice menu, but expensive. The hotel also offers breakfast and high tea, with the Bar Seine serving a shrimp trio for dinner.

The hotel restaurant offers a breakfast buffet with a good variety of hot and cold options, while dinner includes pasta dishes; some reviewers found the restaurant food terrible. A few reviews mention Korean restaurants on 32nd street outside the hotel entrance, with one recommending Hop Kee at 21 Mott street in Chinatown for crabs cantonese.

There is an Italian restaurant, Trattoria Belvedere, next door that some reviewers enjoyed, and the hotel is near many Italian and Indian restaurants. The continental breakfast includes bagels, donuts, and fruit.
This hotel is located in Korea Town, surrounded by Korean restaurants, and near many other restaurants and bars. Some reviewers recommend trying the Korean Barbeque.

The hotel has a restaurant and bar, Opia, with a menu that some reviewers found impressive, although others found mediocre. Some reviewers mentioned a great breakfast next door, a free bar appetizer, or a cheese plate with wine.

The hotel restaurant, Foley's Fishhouse, has a fantastic view of Times Square and has a great menu for dinner and breakfast, although some found it to be overpriced with average quality food. The restaurant has great shrimp cocktail and crabcakes and a S'mores French Toast.

This hotel offers a complimentary hot breakfast buffet with items such as eggs, sausage, french toast, and waffles. There are several restaurants and delis nearby, including Devine Bites, which offers sandwiches, pizza, and pasta.

The Ritz-Carlton Battery Park offers both a restaurant and room service, and several reviewers highlight the food quality and taste. There is also a club level, which provides multiple food presentations throughout the day and breakfast options.

The hotel has a restaurant on the 7th floor with views of Rockefeller Plaza and St. Patrick's Cathedral, and offers room service from The Terrace Club. Some reviewers mentioned nearby dining options like Gordon Ramsey's Restaurant The London.

Lily's, the hotel's restaurant and bar, receives positive feedback for its food, drinks, and service, with specific dishes like the tenderloin and creme brulee mentioned. The hotel also offers a continental breakfast with a variety of options.

The hotel offers an excellent breakfast buffet at a reasonable price for NYC, featuring items like Caneles and prosciutto, as well as amazing espresso for about $20 per person. Some reviewers enjoyed the breakfast buffet and found it to have many choices, while others found it to be overpriced and not worth the cost.

This hotel offers a complimentary continental breakfast with items such as fresh fruit, sweet and savory pastries, cereals, eggs, toast, juice, and coffee. There are also nearby delis for snacks and delivery options from local restaurants are available.

The Royalton has a trendy bar and restaurant serving delicious food, with Brasserie 44 being as good as DB Bistro across the road; room service is available, but the menu is limited and expensive. A great little deli/coffee house is a couple of steps away for grabbing a quick breakfast or bringing coffee to your room, and the Jewel of India is down the street.

The Salisbury Hotel is not specifically mentioned as catering to gourmet lovers, but it is near Carnegie Hall and a short walk to many restaurants. There are reports of a continental breakfast with a $4 charge and some restaurants that deliver to the hotel.

The San Carlos does not have an in-house restaurant, but provides menus for delivery from local restaurants and is near a variety of dining options, including Mint, an Indian restaurant connected to the hotel that offers room service. Some reviewers recommend nearby restaurants such as Ess-a Bagel, Smith & Wollensky, and Morning Star Cafe.
This hotel is located near Union Square which has a Whole Foods Market, restaurants, coffee shops and a farmer's market on select days. There is also a diner and an Irish bar next to the hotel.

The hotel has one restaurant, but many reviewers found it to be expensive and not recommendable, with breakfast costing $27.50; a few reviewers mention Remi and Bar America as excellent restaurants surrounding the hotel. Breakfast in the club room had a large selection of cereals, bagels, pastries, fruit, oatmeal, boiled eggs, yogurt, juices, and coffee, or there was a Starbucks coffee in the room.

The hotel has a restaurant, and is near many restaurants on 9th Ave, diners, and delis including City Lights Diner, Renaissance Diner, and Westside Famous Deli. Reviewers recommend the buffet breakfast, and praise the deli across the street for cheap breakfast.

The hotel restaurant wasn't open during many of the stays; however, there were several good restaurants nearby like Odeon, Pain Quotodien, and Whole Foods. Breakfast was available at Le Pain Quotidien next door, but room service was pricey.

The hotel has a restaurant called Gaby that serves breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Some reviewers enjoyed the complimentary breakfast, while others found it expensive, with a good selection and great service.

The Soho Grand's restaurant food received mixed reviews, with some praising the food in the lobby bar and one reviewer noting the availability of light meals until midnight. Breakfast was a part of some packages and was seen as ok, though one reviewer described the Grand Continental breakfast as a joke.

The hotel has a restaurant with fabulous food, excellent breakfast, and a dining room overlooking the Hudson River; also, food and drink are mentioned as pricey for some cocktails. There are many restaurants and bars in the surrounding area, including Spice Market, Pastis, Budakkan, and Budda Bar.

The hotel has a trendy bar/restaurant (Aspen Social Club) serving light meals and breakfast, but some found the drinks to be very expensive; nearby diners and pubs offer better value. Some guests recommend Evergreen for breakfast, while others advise getting out of the Times Square area for decent food.

The Alex Hotel has a restaurant called Riingo, which serves Japanese cuisine, though some found it overpriced. Some suites have full kitchens with Sub Zero refrigerators and some reviewers recommend the Amish Market across the street.

The hotel has a cafe that serves breakfast, and is near a French restaurant named Pigalle and a Mexican restaurant called Sombrero. Nearby on 9th avenue are restaurants like Vynl, Basilica, Amy's Breads, Dean and Deluca, Gateway Diner, and Westway Diner.

The hotel has a restaurant with good breakfast, and room service food that some reviewers found excellent; others considered it average but expensive. Several reviewers noted the location is close to many restaurants.

The Blakely Hotel has an adjoining Italian restaurant, Abboccato, with room service, a pre-theater menu, and a knowing palate for wines; complimentary continental breakfast is offered but cooked breakfast is available at an extra cost. Some reviewers found the restaurant overpriced with small portions while others thought it had some of the best food.

The hotel restaurant, Gemma, serves Italian food and is popular with locals; breakfast is considered good, and room service is available from Gemma. Some reviewers recommend nearby restaurants like Il Buco and Graffiti.

The Bryant Park Hotel has a Japanese restaurant, Koi, on premises that serves sushi and fusion Asian cooking, and room service from Koi is available. The hotel is near many delis, and "Pain Quotidien" is a nearby breakfast option.

The Carlton offers a restaurant, Country, that holds gourmet standards with a pleasant surprise wine list, and a downstairs Country Bistro with a breakfast menu that some guests found adequate, while others felt the pastries were ordinary. Some guests recommend delis in the surrounding blocks as alternatives to the hotel breakfast.

The Carlyle offers a restaurant with a formal dining room, requiring jackets at dinner, and a breakfast buffet with items like blueberry muffins. Some reviewers enjoyed meals such as Eggs Benedict, while others found the food average and overpriced.

The hotel offers a complimentary continental breakfast with artisan bread, cheeses, pastries, yogurt, and coffee, as well as an evening wine and cheese reception. Some reviewers mention the breakfast includes prosciutto, fresh fruit, and a cappuccino maker.
The hotel is located on Restaurant Row, surrounded by various dining options, including the Bourbon Street bar downstairs. The continental breakfast includes pastries, fruits, and coffee.
The hotel is located in Chelsea, close to many restaurants, including F&B Gudtfood, Spice (Thai), and Murray's Bagels. Numerous restaurants in the area also deliver to the rooms.
These reviews do not contain information on gourmet food, so I cannot create a summary that is relevant to the query.

The Gem Soho is located near Katz's Deli, Russ & Daughters, Yonah Schimmel's Knishes, and Whole Foods, with some rooms including a mini-fridge and microwave. Several reviewers recommend nearby restaurants such as Sugar Diner, Freeman's, and The Elephant.
I am sorry, but there is no information about gourmet experiences at the hotel.

Some reviewers appreciated the complimentary breakfast, which included a different hot item each morning, 
as well as cereals, pastries, breads, fruit juice, and coffee. Some reviewers mentioned nearby restaurants with delicious food.
The hotel is close to many restaurants within walking distance. Some rooms come with a kitchen.

The Helmsley Park Lane hotel has a restaurant with Central Park views, "A Room with a View," that has been completely and tastefully renovated; the hotel restaurant served the "best steaks" some visitors had in New York. Breakfast is available in the Park Room with views, but some prefer Sarabeth's next door, though both are considered pricey.
The hotel does not have a restaurant, but is located near many restaurants, including Koreatown. There is also a trendy restaurant-cafe next-door and a high end chocolate and wine restaurant.

This hotel is in the heart of Chinatown, surrounded by Chinese restaurants and within walking distance of Little Italy; a restaurant called Bacaro is nearby on Division Street. Some reviewers noted the fish market in the street adds to the local flavor, and there are bakeries next door to the hotel.
This hotel has a cozy bar/lounge and is near many restaurants, including Brazilian, Italian, delis, and the Monster Sushi. There is a breakfast buffet, and a coffee maker in the room.

Lady Mendl's Tea Salon offers a 5-course tea service in an opulent dining room and breakfast includes pastries from Balthazar. The hotel has a bar downstairs, Cybar, that serves cocktails, champagne and a selection of beers, and the food served at wedding receptions is delicious.

The Iroquois features the Triomphe restaurant, which offers a 6-course tasting menu and seasonal menu with the food receiving glowing reviews. Some reviewers also mention the complimentary coffee and iced tea, while others enjoyed the Red Flame Diner down the block for breakfast.

I'm sorry, but the provided hotel reviews do not contain any information about gourmet food or dining experiences. Therefore, I cannot generate a summary that includes information relevant to that topic.

George O'Neill's steakhouse is connected to the hotel and serves a buffet breakfast; also, there are plentiful restaurants within walking distance, including Houston's on 3rd and PJ Clarkes across the street. There is also a little diner for breakfast brunch next door to the hotel, and the restaurant Ferro's offers basic, well-prepared brunch food.

The Lombardy has an adjacent restaurant, Table XII, and offers room service from a nearby restaurant; every room has a kitchenette. There are many restaurants, diners, delis and bars within a block of the hotel.

The London NYC has two Gordon Ramsay restaurants: a casual one called Maze and an exclusive one; afternoon tea is also served. Some reviewers found the food superb, with the tasting menu and wine selection receiving praise, but others found it overpriced with small portions.

The Lucerne is next to Nice Matin, a Mediterranean restaurant; breakfast at Nice Matin is offered at a discount, or you can find bagels at H&H Bagels and deli items at Zabar's nearby. Some reviewers recommend Ottomanelli Brothers for breakfast, Coppolla's for Italian, Sarabeth's, and Good Enough to Eat.
These hotel reviews do not contain information about the hotels being good for "gourmet lovers". However, they do mention several restaurants and delis within walking distance.

The Mansfield Hotel has a cocktail bar/restaurant with a literary leather and cigar vibe, as well as a pub/restaurant beside it with excellent service. Breakfast is included and consists of bagels, muffins, fresh fruit juice, toast, cereals, and yoghurt coffee.

The hotel has a restaurant, Inoteca, downstairs in the lobby that is very good with a great cocktail bar and has a real New York neighborhood feel; there are also many restaurants located within walking distance. Sunflower Diner is a block or two north of the hotel and there is a restaurant next door that is fab.

The Maritime Hotel has an Italian restaurant, La Bottega, that serves good breakfast, lunch, and room service, as well as a Japanese restaurant, Matsuri, with a menu available for room service. Chelsea Market is located across the street with many options for lunch or dinner.
The Mark has a restaurant and bar, and some reviewers mention complimentary breakfast or snacks. One reviewer received cookies from a restaurant down the street.

The hotel offers fully equipped kitchens in its suites and is located near grocery stores and a deli, with restaurants such as Nick's serving generous portions of Italian food nearby. Some reviewers mention specific restaurants in the area, including Candle Cafe, Cafe Alsace, and Sarabeth's.

The Mave hotel offers a "grab and go" breakfast with coffee and danishes, but no seating is available. Some reviewers mention the breakfast included artisanal cheeses and French breads, while others found it lacking variety and suggest nearby cafes for more options.

The hotel has a bistro-like restaurant in the basement called The Mercer Kitchen, and the lobby serves breakfast and food from the restaurant. The mini-bar has a selection of gourmet items and the hotel is near Dean & Deluca.

The Michelangelo Hotel has an upscale Italian restaurant called "Insieme" which some reviewers enjoyed, while others found the food soulless and the service lacking. The hotel also offers a complimentary breakfast with croissants, scones, and coffee.

The Milburn Hotel is near Zabar's deli and Fairway Market, which offer a variety of wonderful meals and delis in a reasonable price range, and the Manhattan Diner offers 24-hour room service. Some rooms have kitchenettes.

The Muse Hotel offers a restaurant called The District which serves imaginative dishes, and a $35 pre-theatre 3 course meal. The hotel is also near many restaurants including Havana Central, a Spanish restaurant, Bubba Gump, and vegetarian restaurants.

The hotel has a restaurant but many reviewers recommend eating out, with Pershing Square being a popular breakfast spot and Pax Deli being a good option for take-out. Some reviewers found the food at Mindy's restaurant to be good, but the wine prices high.

The New Yorker Hotel has an attached Tick Tock Diner which serves generous portions but may be considered over-priced; Cooper's Tavern is also attached, but some reviewers found the bar staff expect larger than normal tips. Some reviewers recommend other diners and restaurants nearby for better value and food quality.
The hotel has a new restaurant called Caprice and a lobby lounge with a cocktail menu, in addition to Cafe Pierre. The hotel also offers room service.

The hotel has a restaurant (Oak Room) with mixed reviews, expensive dining, and a bar/restaurant that appeared closed. Some guests received gourmet chocolates, and one reviewer recommends a nearby restaurant called Sarabeths.

Le Bateau Ivre, a French bistro is located next door to the hotel, while the hotel does not have a restaurant but tons of dining options are available in the immediate area including PAX, Azure, and a number of ethnic restaurants. Some reviewers recommend the Morning Star Diner for breakfast.

The hotel offers room service with items such as a chicken wrap and cake, and includes a complimentary breakfast buffet. Some reviews mention Virgil's Barbecue right across the street, and Cafe 123 a few doors down.

The hotel offers five different food and drink servings a day in the club lounge, and guests can enjoy Afternoon Tea in the Star Lounge or dine at the BLT Market. Some reviewers recommend Sarabeth's, located near the hotel, for breakfast or brunch.
The hotel restaurant is expensive but has good food and there is a bar in the lobby that serves food. The hotel is near many cheap breakfast and dinner places with good food and many delis.

The hotel offers room service from Cipriani's, and some suites have kitchens and ice makers. A complimentary breakfast is included, and the rooms are stocked with complimentary soft drinks, juices, and Godiva chocolates.

The hotel has a restaurant and a bar that serves a good buffet breakfast and good food that is artfully presented, with a menu available 24 hours. Some recent reviewers enjoyed the continental breakfast, as well as nearby restaurants such as the Italian restaurant Il Corso.

The hotel offers Alain Ducasse restaurant for fine dining, the Astor Court for afternoon tea or breakfast, and the King Cole Bar. Some reviewers highlight the expensive but tasty room service and the availability of prix fixe lunch and dinner options.
The Standard Grill is located in the hotel, offering good food for a good value with breakfast, lunch, and dinner options. Some guests recommend trying the Standard burger, and mention the brioche.

The Surrey has an in-house restaurant, Cafe Boulud, which is considered one of the better restaurants in New York, with innovative dishes, attentive service, and a well-deserved star in guide michelin. The restaurant provides room service to hotel guests.
I am sorry, but the hotel reviews provided do not contain any information about gourmet experiences.

Serefina restaurant is located in the building, offering good food with a 20% discount to hotel guests; Carmines in Times Square is another great option, offering great quality Italian food at low prices. The hotel also offers a trendy bar, and guests can get a 20% off voucher for the Serefina restaurant and a buy-one-get-one-free voucher for the lounge.

The hotel has multiple dining options including Bull & Bear, Oscars, and Peacock Alley, but reviewers note that they are expensive; Sunday brunch is $95/person. Smith and Wollensky is also a few minutes walk away, and breakfast at the Rock Center Cafe is exceptional.

Shula's Steakhouse is located in the hotel, though some guests found the food and drinks expensive and the breakfast food quality to be just okay. There are a variety of large and small well-priced restaurants within a few blocks’ walking distance.

The hotel has an attached restaurant called Zana, which some reviewers found pricey and with good food while others found it disappointing and not good value; across the road is The Crooked Knife bar and restaurant, which some reviewers recommend. California Pizza Kitchen is also nearby.

The Thompson LES has a restaurant called Shang with a good menu, though some found the layout and decor questionable. Some reviewers enjoyed the food at Shang, and there are nearby dining options, including Russ & Daughters and Cafe Charbon.
This hotel has a deli next door, delivers food to the rooms until 1 am and is near many local eateries. There is also a Deli and diner next door or across the street from the hotel.

The hotel restaurant is mentioned as having excellent food, a great Sunday brunch, a delicious breakfast, and well-made cocktails. Some reviewers enjoyed late-night goat cheese and arugula pizza, and complimentary breakfasts with a full American breakfast delivered to the room.
The hotel offers room service from Jean Georges Restaurant, as well as a casual dining option at Nougatine. Some rooms include kitchenettes and full kitchens with Le Bernardin plates.

The hotel restaurant offers a pricey American buffet breakfast, with one reviewer recommending the Oyster Bar Restaurant at Grand Central. A few reviewers recommend nearby restaurants such as PAX, Teresa's, and Johns Cafe.

The hotel has a bar that opens in the evenings, a breakfast buffet that includes fresh fruit, and a Japanese buffet restaurant next door; some reviewers mentioned nearby dining options in Korea Town, while others found the hotel breakfast expensive and preferred local bagel shops. Some reviewers enjoyed the complimentary breakfast, while others found it lacking or not consistently offered.
The hotel has an on-site restaurant called ICON, and is near a variety of restaurants on Lexington Ave. and a food hall at Grand Central Terminal.

The hotel is next door to W Court, where breakfast is available at Audrey's, and the Wet Bar has a great selection of cocktails. There is a small cafe around the corner that has a cheap and great breakfast and even better coffee.

The W Times Square has a Blue Fin restaurant with superb cocktails and seafood and is known for its desserts. The Blue Fin offers a delicious breakfast and some reviewers mentioned the excellence of room service.

The hotel restaurant, Olives, is a Todd English establishment that is wonderfully gourmet, but can be pricey; breakfast can be a nightmare with chillout music blasting. Some reviewers recommend the hotel for its proximity to the Union Square Greenmarket, which offers local produce and goodies several days a week.

The hotel has several on-site restaurants including the Bull and Bear steakhouse and Oscar's, with room service offering similar choices to Oscar's menu. Breakfast is available in the Astoria Lounge, and some suites include kitchenettes and wet bars.

The hotel is located near Stone Street eateries, and behind the hotel is a pedestrian-friendly street with a neat assortment of restaurants. Carry-out menus are available in the room, and the hotel serves continental breakfast.

The Warwick Hotel has two on-site options: Murals on 54th, which serves a nice breakfast buffet, and Randolph's bar, which serves light food and drinks. Some reviewers found Murals on 54th to be expensive, and in-room dining is also available for breakfast.

The hotel is connected to a classic sushi restaurant, Shimizu, and is near many restaurants, including Braai, serving South African barbecue-style dishes and others in restaurant row. There's also a gourmet delicatessen and several delicious bagel shops nearby and a pub next door serving good brews.

The Washington Square Hotel has an attached restaurant, North Square, that serves a complimentary continental breakfast and gourmet lunch and dinner. Babbo Restaurant, run by Mario Battali, is located across the street.

There is a Greek restaurant in the hotel called Molyvos, known as one of the best restaurants in town with great drinks, also Park Cafe serves a good breakfast and food. There are multiple dining options nearby, including Carnegie Deli and Fluffy's Cafe.

The hotel has an owner's lounge that serves continental breakfast and evening hors d'oeuvres catered by the nearby Redeye Grill, including Kobe beef pigs in a blanket and shrimp dumplings. There is no in-house restaurant or room service, but some reviewers mention nearby restaurants like Le Cirque, Ruth Chris, and Brooklyn Diner.

The hotel offers a free breakfast with eggs, sausage or bacon, waffles, pastries, and fruit. There is a Creole restaurant opening in July and a restaurant attached to the hotel with a 10% discount for guests.

This hotel offers complimentary coffee and muffins in the lobby and is near a variety of eateries including delis, a 24-hour breakfast place called Speedy's, Smith and Wollensky's steakhouse, a pizza shop, a donut-coffee shop, Korean restaurants, and an Irish pub. Some reviewers also mentioned a superb 24-hour breakfast place called Speedy's.

This location is near Fairway-market, a grocery store, and Zabars, and some rooms feature a kitchenette. There is also an awesome restaurant for breakfast less than 2 blocks away and Sarabeths, which is a famous breakfast venue.
The hotel restaurant is described as upscale, with great service and excellent food. The hotel has a restaurant that offers organic food and also has a good bar.
